content.title: Syncope Evaluation
content.summary: Syncope is transient loss of consciousness due to cerebral hypoperfusion, with spontaneous complete recovery. Evaluation aims to distinguish benign reflex syncope from potentially life-threatening cardiac syncope. Initial assessment includes history, physical exam with orthostatic vitals, and ECG. Risk stratification guides further workup and disposition.
key_points: Three categories: Reflex (vasovagal, situational), Orthostatic, Cardiac (most dangerous)
History is most important: Triggers, prodrome, position, witnesses, recovery
ECG in all patients - may reveal arrhythmia or structural heart disease
Cardiac syncope: Exertional, supine, palpitations, family history sudden death
Risk stratification: Age, heart failure, structural heart disease, abnormal ECG
Tilt table test for recurrent unexplained syncope when reflex suspected
content.statement: Syncope evaluation focuses on distinguishing benign reflex syncope from potentially fatal cardiac syncope through history, examination, ECG, and risk stratification to guide appropriate workup and management.

explanation.intuition: Think of syncope as the brain's 'power outage' from not getting enough blood. The key question is: why did the power go out? Was it a simple blown fuse (vasovagal - blood vessels dilated too much) or is there a problem with the main generator (heart arrhythmia or structural disease)?
explanation.key_insight: HISTORY is the most powerful diagnostic tool - 45% of cases diagnosed by history alone. Key features: What was the patient doing (standing, exertion, supine)? Were there prodromal symptoms (warmth, nausea = vasovagal)? Witness account of duration and any convulsive movements (prolonged syncope can cause brief 'convulsive syncope').
explanation.technical_details: Syncope requires transient global cerebral hypoperfusion. Mean arterial pressure drops to ~60mmHg or cerebral perfusion stops for 6-8 seconds to cause LOC. Reflex syncope involves cardioinhibitory (bradycardia) and/or vasodepressor (hypotension) responses. Cardiac output = stroke volume × heart rate; cardiac syncope results from sudden drop in either.

definitions_glossary.syncope: Transient loss of consciousness due to cerebral hypoperfusion with spontaneous recovery
definitions_glossary.presyncope: Prodromal symptoms without complete loss of consciousness
definitions_glossary.vasovagal_syncope: Reflex syncope from vagal activation causing bradycardia and vasodilation
definitions_glossary.situational_syncope: Reflex syncope triggered by specific activities (cough, micturition, defecation)
definitions_glossary.orthostatic_syncope: Syncope from blood pressure drop upon standing
definitions_glossary.orthostatic_hypotension: SBP drop ≥20mmHg or DBP drop ≥10mmHg within 3 minutes of standing
definitions_glossary.cardiac_syncope: Syncope from arrhythmia or structural heart disease
definitions_glossary.carotid_sinus_syndrome: Reflex syncope from hypersensitive carotid baroreceptors
definitions_glossary.tilt_table_test: Provocative test reproducing vasovagal syncope in controlled setting
definitions_glossary.implantable_loop_recorder: ILR - subcutaneous device for long-term arrhythmia monitoring
definitions_glossary.TLOC: Transient loss of consciousness - broad term including syncope and non-syncopal causes
definitions_glossary.convulsive_syncope: Brief clonic movements during prolonged syncope; mimics seizure

pathophysiology.mechanism: Syncope results from transient global cerebral hypoperfusion due to decreased cardiac output or peripheral vascular resistance

reflex.vasovagal: Emotional or orthostatic stress → parasympathetic activation → bradycardia + vasodilation
reflex.situational: Specific triggers (cough, micturition, defecation, swallowing) activate reflex
reflex.carotid_sinus: Carotid baroreceptor hypersensitivity → bradycardia or hypotension

orthostatic.mechanism: Inadequate compensatory response to upright position

initial_evaluation.ECG: ALL patients - look for arrhythmia, conduction disease, long QT, Brugada, WPW

high_risk_features: Family history of sudden cardiac death
Known structural heart disease or heart failure
Abnormal ECG (heart block, long QT, preexcitation, Q waves)

differential_diagnosis: Seizure (prolonged confusion, tongue biting, urinary incontinence)
Psychogenic pseudosyncope (eyes closed, frequent events, normal BP)

reflex_syncope.education: Recognize prodrome, abort with counter-pressure maneuvers
reflex_syncope.lifestyle: Adequate hydration, salt intake, avoid triggers
reflex_syncope.refractory: Consider midodrine, fludrocortisone; pacing rarely indicated

further_workup.cardiac_monitoring: Holter (frequent), event monitor, implantable loop recorder (rare)
further_workup.electrophysiology_study: Suspected arrhythmic syncope with non-diagnostic workup

definition.@value: A systematic approach to evaluating transient loss of consciousness to distinguish benign reflex syncope from life-threatening cardiac causes

scopeNote.@value: Covers classification, evaluation, risk stratification, and management of syncope

learning_objectives: Classify syncope into reflex, orthostatic, and cardiac categories
Obtain focused history to distinguish syncope from seizure
Identify high-risk features suggesting cardiac syncope
Apply appropriate risk stratification to guide workup
Select appropriate diagnostic testing based on clinical suspicion
clinical_pearls: History diagnoses 45% of syncope - listen carefully to patient and witnesses
ECG in ALL syncope patients - may be only clue to cardiac cause
Exertional or supine syncope = cardiac until proven otherwise
Vasovagal prodrome: warmth, nausea, diaphoresis, tunnel vision
Convulsive syncope can occur - don't assume seizure just because of brief jerks
common_misconceptions: All LOC with convulsions is seizure - convulsive syncope exists
Young patients don't have cardiac syncope - HCM, long QT can present young
Normal ECG rules out cardiac syncope - intermittent arrhythmias may be missed
